items.title: Ground Radar John Wood’s Ledger Stone
items.summary: 14th November 2022 Last week Bristol University visited St Mary’s Church at Upper Swainswick, the final resting place of John…
items.content_html:
14th November 2022

Last week Bristol University visited St Mary’s Church at Upper Swainswick, the final resting place of John Wood the Elder and his family members.

They carried out ground radar analysis above the ledger stones of John Wood the Elder and one of his daughters to try and find out whether there is a family vault below and whether their are more people interred beneath.

Read more at bathnewseum.com

items.title: Conveyance for 14 The Circus, Bath
items.summary: 20th July 2022 Ancestor Homes has a very interesting article on House History: An in depth look at the 1764…
items.content_html:
20th July 2022

Ancestor Homes has a very interesting article on House History: An in depth look at the 1764 Conveyance for 14 The Circus, Bath.

 

It provides an insight into how John Wood the Elder acquired the land The Circus is built on:

The Conveyance then describes how John Wood acquired the land in the first place. Wood had purchased the land off ‘Thomas Garrard late of the Inner Temple London Esquire/since deceased/and Margaret his wife’ along with Samuel Purlewent, also a Gentleman of Bath, who had died by the time of the Conveyance. The parties had signed a deed dated 1 November 1754 for nine acres of land at a yearly rent of £163 (approximately £20,000 in today’s money).

It goes on to also ensure that the exterior of the buildings that form the The Circus, Bath are to be uniform and adhere to the design:

The Conveyance then goes on to ensure the outside of all premises on the Circus is uniform. No chimneys could be altered without the consent of John Wood and stonework was to be cleansed and tombed so no cracks appeared. The deed also contains a clause about the colour of the woodwork; ‘the whole building may be of one colour and also shall and will paint all of the woodwork in the outside of the said messuage and also the outside street door with a quite white colour’.

items.content_html:
3th July 2022

March 2023 sees the National Trust taking over the Bath Assembly Rooms. They have owned them since 1931 but have leased it to the North East Somerset Council who have housed the Fashion Museum their.

See the update from The National Trust and their plan for Bath Assembly Rooms.

The Bath Assembly Rooms were designed by John Wood the Younger 1769-1771

May 2022 will see the newly illustrated and revised edition of ‘Architect of Obsession : John Wood and the Creation Bath’ by Timothy Mowl & Brian Earnshaw with Cathryn Spence. For anyone interested in more details on the life and history of John Wood this is a must have.

My copy of the original is well worn and I cannot wait for the new edition. Its 304 pages have been beautifully updated with new photos and colour illustrations.

items.title: John Wood the Elder’s Graves Restored
items.summary: 2nd March 2022 Just under 3 miles North East from the centre of Bath is Upper Swainswick. Here at St…
items.content_html:
2nd March 2022

Just under 3 miles North East from the centre of Bath is Upper Swainswick. Here at St Marys’s Church is the resting place of John Wood the Elder, his son and other family members. Across the valley is the wonderful All Saints Church, Woolley designed by John Wood the Younger.

The memorial slabs are being restored to bring back the wonderful lettering. A very minimal monument to the Georgian Architect who gave Bath the identity it has today.

Read more about it here:

  • bathnewseum.com

  • Bath Magazine

items.title: John Wood the Elder’s Drawing Instruments
items.summary: 14th February 2022 In 2016 the Bath Preservation Trust was able to purchase at auction the drawing instruments owned by…
items.content_html:
14th February 2022

In 2016 the Bath Preservation Trust was able to purchase at auction the drawing instruments owned by John Wood the Elder. They paid £21,000 for the set that was made around 1745 by the leading architectural instrument maker Thomas Heath of London.

The set is housed in a silver and fish skin case which has his familiar coat of arms. Inside the case comprises a silver scale ruler, an ivory sector ruler with silver mounts, compass, dividers, bow, two pens and a pencil. 

The set is on display at the Museum of Bath Architecture.
